title.narrative: Women and girls who have experienced/are experiencing GBV or are at risk of GBV benefit from provision of and access to quality services and empowered to increasingly engage in decision making and leadership in GBV response, mitigation and prevention.

description.narrative:
This objective of this UN Women multi-country programme is to provide survivors of GBV and those at risk of GBV with livelihoods and agency to facilitate their access to lifesaving humanitarian services and facilitate their voices in promoting GBV accountability in humanitarian contexts. The impact of the programme will be to more effectively mitigate, prevent and respond to GBV amongst crisis affected communities. UN Women interventions focus on three outcomes, two of them to be jointly achieved with UNFPA. The three key outcomes of the project cover aspects of social norm programming that will contribute to protection and empowerment of crisis affected women and girls in priority countries; scaling up partnerships with local WLOs/WROs and strengthening their capacities to participate in humanitarian decision making; increasing access and improving quality of services provided to crisis affected women and girls (refugees, IDPs and in host communities) both in relation to protection and livelihoods/income generation (including cash for women). The program will also contribute to the protection and address the needs and priorities of at risk and marginalized groups including LGBTIQ+ populations, women and girls with disabilities.
The project is designed to be sustainable and continue yielding positive impact after the implementation period concludes.
This $8mil project targets 176,610 affected people with Protection/GBV engagement, 5,684 with Food Security and 732 affected people with specific multi-sector cash assistance modalities.

title.narrative: Provision of Nutrition services for Severe Acute malnourished children Populations affected with COVID 19 in Balochistan.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving emergency nutrition services for SAM-affected children at health facilities and communities. This UNICEF project provides 1) 29 outpatient nutrition sites, 2) nutrition commodities (RUTF, Iron Folic Acid, Multi-micronutrient supplements), 3) sessions on nutrition, hygiene and health promotion in the nutrition sites and 4) multiple micronutrients supplements (MMS) and Iron Folic Acid (IFA) for children and Pregnant and Lactating Mothers (PLW) among other activities. The project provides life-saving assistance to 417,017 including 302,451 women, over 100,000 children and over 54,000 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Lifesaving support for nutrition and WASH services in Yemen

description.narrative:
Under the proposed activities, UNICEF will provide life-saving nutrition and WASH support to vulnerable communities in Yemen. UNICEF will target 435,394 children and pregnant and lactating women (PLW) with activities in support of overall nutritional status and 3 million people will benefit from Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) activities to support access to safe water. The dual-pronged approach of support to both nutrition and WASH is imperative to support to overall better health of the Yemeni population.
Nutrition activities include screening and referral of children under 5 and pregnant and lactating mothers to prevent further nutritional deterioration. Therapeutic treatment will be provided to children who are referred for treatment, through the procurement and delivery of therapeutic food and medicines.
Building on previous UNICEF WASH intervention achievements in Yemen with different donors’ support, the proposed project aims to enhance UNICEF Emergency WASH interventions to improve and sustain WASH service provision in conflict affected and vulnerable communities in Sana'a, Marib, Mukalla, Lahj, Ataq, Hudaida, Hajjah, Saada, Al Jawf Ibb, Taizz, Dhamar, Amran, Al Mahweet, Raimeh governorates in Yemen and preventing the disease such as cholera, and COVID_19 spread in at risk communities. WASH service provision is a key underpinning to the general health of the population of Yemen, mitigating risk of disease thorough access to safe drinking water, and sanitation and hygiene.

title.narrative: Delivery of Nutrition and WASH services for reduction of mortality and morbidity in Afghanistan in COVID-19 context

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide lifesaving Nutrition and WASH services to contribute to the reduction of morbidity and mortality in the current COVID-19 context. This UNICEF project pre-positions Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) therapeutic supplies, provides water through water trucking, repair and/or rehabilitate existing, installs new water supply systems, distributes hygiene kits and consumable items (soap bars/sanitary pads) and promotes hand washing with soap among other activities. The project provides life-saving assistance to 70,000 people, including 14,850 women, 14,850 men, 40,000 children, and 7,700 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Child Protection and Education in Emergency response for children affected by conflict in Northeast of Nigeria

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving child protection and education assistance to vulnerable communities in Adamawa, Borno and Yobe states. The child protection component of this UNICEF project supports vulnerable children including through family tracing and reunification for unaccompanied and separated children; provides comprehensive case management for children formerly associated with armed groups; delivers psychosocial support interventions for caregivers affected by mental health distress; and strengthens community-based efforts to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in children. The education component of this project provides education materials including home-/distance-learning materials; delivers educational radio broadcasts; supports alternative teaching through the use of smart phones and/or tablets for teachers; trains teachers and school-based management committees on psycho-social support; raises awareness about COVID-19 infection prevention and control measures; procures personal protective equipment for teachers, children and school committees to prevent the spread of the disease; rehabilitates of temporary learning spaces and classrooms; and provides dignity kits to young girls. The education component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 67,800 people, including 400 women, 700 men, 66,700 children, and 1,500 people with disabilities. The child protection component provides life-saving assistance to 37,650 people, including 570 women, 580 men, 36,500 children, and 250 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Preventing child recruitment in Chocó and Nariño and responding to COVID-19 in indigenous communities in Amazonas

description.narrative: This $1 million UNICEF project has three main objectives: (1) protecting at-risk communities from abuse, sexual violence, and recruitment by armed groups, (2) ensure safe water supply, (3) mitigate the impacts of COVID-19 on education in remote areas. To that end, UNICEF and its implementing partners will set up 25 recruitment prevention pathways, train 800 community leaders about child recruitment prevention, set up 9 local action teams for prevention of child abuse, recruitment and sexual violence, distribute 50 kits (containing clothing, personal hygiene items and protection messages) to minors at imminent risk of recruitment, and provide psychosocial support to 8,100 children and their caregivers affected by armed conflict. UNICEF and its implementing partners will also provide 6,500 people with hygiene items, rehabilitate seven water supply systems (replacement of water tanks, installation of electric pumps, etc.), conduct 20 workshops for community leaders on healthy COVID-19 practices. In addition, UNICEF will provide 3,564 children with material for home-based learning, help 37 schools in implementing protocols for COVID-19 prevention and control, and train 190 teachers in distance learning practices. In total, UNICEF aims to reach 30,316 people, including 7,990 women and 6,855 girls. Among those targeted UNICEF estimates to be 668 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: TEAM: Time-critical Emergency Agriculture inputs assistance to Marginal and food insecure farming households to mitigate impacts of COVID-19 and ongoing food crisis

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to protect the agriculture livelihoods of vulnerable marginal farming households from the adverse impacts of COVID-19 shock and worsening of existing food crisis. This FAO project provides winter wheat production packages including wheat seeds and fertilizer, and training, information dissemination and awareness building on COVID-19 safety measures to adopt at farm level practices. The project provides life-saving assistance to 260400 people, including 52,210 women, 51,950 men, over 150,000 children, including 7,000 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Providing the Minimum Initial Service Package for Reproductive Health (RH) to the most vulnerable women and girls in Yemen

description.narrative:
Access to and availability of maternal and new-born health services has been grossly undermined by the protracted crisis. The combination of YER depreciation, food insecurity, and the COVID-19 pandemic has led to greatly increased vulnerabilities of women of reproductive age particularly pregnant women. According to the WHO Health Resources Availability Monitoring System (HeRAMS) conducted in 2018, only 20 percent of health facilities in Yemen provided maternal and new-born health services, a decrease from 37 percent reported in 2016. UNFPA field assessments have confirmed gaps in RH services that require urgent interventions such as staffing, equipment, and medicine needed for providing life-saving Emergency Obstetric and Neonatal Care (EmONC) services.
CERF will directly lead to the resumption of critical life-saving RH services in 55 health facilities in districts with the highest severity indices. All the targeted facilities stopped providing these critical services on May 16th due to UNFPA's funding shortage. The supported facilities will provide women and girls with the life-saving essential reproductive health services, particularly those related to complicated deliveries and care for survivors of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV) and Sexual Violence. CERF will also support 100 community midwives and outreach teams. These teams will be reaching the most vulnerable women and girls in the most remote areas.
Additionally, the project will be complemented by GBV mitigation and response interventions within the targeted health facilities. It will also be complemented by the Cash and Voucher Assistance interventions UNFPA implements to enhance the accessibility of those in the most remote areas to services.

title.narrative: Urgent Response to the Impact of COVID-19 on the protection of refugees, particularly women and children in Uganda

description.narrative: This project aims to provide comprehensive protection response to address critical protection needs, both underlying and those have emerged as a result of the Covid-19 crisis. UNHCR and partners will: establish and maintain one-stop drop-in centers at health facilities for GBV survivors; improve existing safe shelters to accommodate the increased number of survivors in the COVID-19 context; strengthen case management capacities to support and assist 2,300 children at risk and GBV survivors to ensure that children in need access protection services; increase quality of documentation and management of services through ProGres v.4; expand provide child protection and SGBV case management modules and GBVIMS by recruiting, equipping and deploying 38 additional case workers for SGBV and Child Protection; expand MHPSS services; provide survivors and at-risk individuals with unrestricted multi-purpose cash transfers and basic financial literacy skills. project aims to provide comprehensive protection response to address underfunded critical protection needs, and those that are now emerging as a resukt of the Covid-19 crisis. UNHCR and partners will: establish and maintain one-stop drop-in centers at health facilities for GBV survivors; improve existing safe shelters to accommodate the increased number of survivors in the COVID-19 context; strengthen case management capacities to support and assist 2,300 children at risk and GBV survivors to ensure that children in need access protection services; increase quality of documentation and management of services through ProGres v.4; expand provide child protection and SGBV case management modules and GBVIMS by recruiting, equipping and deploying 38 additional case workers for SGBV and Child Protection; expand MHPSS services; provide survivors and at-risk individuals with unrestricted multi-purpose cash transfers and basic financial literacy skills.

title.narrative: Protection for victims of forced displacement and confinement in times of COVID-19.

description.narrative: The main aim of this $743,151 UNHCR project is provision of protection mechanisms for IDPs and others at risk as well as reducing the protection gaps related to SGBV. Among key activities UNHCR will equip 8 community infrastructures for IDPs with shelter material and energy sources, install 20 refugee housing units, and train 184 public servants in psychosocial care for IDPs, provide 1450 humanitarian kits to 5,800 beneficiaries, and support 340 SGBV survivors with case management. In total, UNHCR aims to reach 17,954 persons, including 4,938 women and 3,133 girls (and including 179 persons with disabilities).

title.narrative: Multisector humanitarian assistance for populations affected by insecurity in Cabo Delgado, Mozambique

title.narrative: Improving the living conditions of displaced populations in north-east Nigeria through Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM) and Shelter assistance.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving shelter, essential household item, and camp coordination assistance to vulnerable communities in Adamawa and Borno states. This IOM project supports the decongestion in Pulka town, providers materials to construct new shelters for internally-displaced people, constructs latrines and showers, distributes essential household item kits to resettled families, renovates two reception facilities, provides camp/site management support in 9 camps, raises awareness about COVID-19, and establishes 4 temporary community outreach centres. The camp management component of the project provides life-saving assistance to 143,000 people, including 31,600 women, 12,240 men, 89,900 children, and 2,200 people with disabilities. The shelter component provides life-saving assistance to 16,500 people, including 3,500 women, 2,500 men, 10,500 children and 800 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Providing life-saving food assistance and restore food security of victims of the internal conflict and COVID-affected ethnic groups in Chocó, Nariño and Amazonas regions

description.narrative: The aim of this $889,521 WFP project is to ensure food security through food assistance and early recovery actions to victims of the internal conflict and COVID-affected indigenous populations. To that end, WFP will procure and distribute 314 metric tons of food (cereals, pulses and oils), cash and vouchers worth $379,315 for 4,150 people and training for livelihood restoring for 500 people. In total, WFP plans to reach 15,868 people, of whom 3,788 women and 4,716 girls and including 477 persons with disabilities.

title.narrative: Strengthening Integrated prevention and response services to address SGBV & Nutrition related health and protection needs in post-COVID situation

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide support for strengthening provision of GBV related life-saving prevention, protection and health care response and improve equitable access to essential integrated lifesaving nutrition services for children less than five years old and Pregnant and lactating Women. This WHO project provides specialised GBV related health care, clinical management and psycho-social support services, trains Community Health Workers to deliver GBV-related promotional messages and mobile psycho-social support, establishes two Nutrition Stabilization Centres (SC) and provides F75, F100, Resomal and other SC medicines and SC kits among other activities. The project provides life-saving assistance to 19,000 people, including 8,560 women, 3,090 men, 7,350 children, and 3,200 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Provision of essential and lifesaving health services for vulnerable population

description.narrative:
The project will support Minimum Services Packages (MSP), Therapeutic Feeding Center(TFC) and Trauma care in targeted health facilities.
The support to the MSP will focus on 21 health facilities located in Lahji, Ibb and Al Dhale governorates. This intervention will aim to providing essential medical services to over 274,000 people. Essential medical services are those defined as per first line response under the Yemen Humanitarian Response Plan (YHRP): primary care including ante-natal and post-natal care, lifesaving services requiring surgical consultations and treatment of severely acute malnourished children under five.
The CERF allocation will target 90 therapeutic feeding centres directly supported by WHO, covering 222 high priority districts in 22 governorates by providing essential drugs (SAM kits) and admission kits; these kits are gender responsive and child friendly as they include hygiene items for mothers and children when SAM children are admitted to the TFCs and other essential products like baby clothing to reduce the economic burden on families during the SAM children’ admission period. WHO will be targeting 23,428 SAM children along with their caregivers (mothers) with counselling on Infant and Young Child Feeding-IYCF, infection prevention and control measures and for breastfeeding in COVID_19.
The project will ensure access of integrated trauma care through providing trauma care package and continuity of care at supported hospitals setting up life-saving integrated trauma system; strengthen the capacity of trauma surgeons and health staff working in supported hospitals to effectively manage trauma emergency care service; providing trauma medical supplies for 23 hospitals.

title.narrative: To ensure provision of health services in areas affected by natural disasters, mass causality incidences and diseases outbreaks

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to ensure life-saving trauma care, primary healthcare, nutrition and WASH services are provided effectively in hard to reach and underserved areas. This WHO project trains 650 HCWs on early detection and reporting of COVID-19, trains contact tracing team on tracing contacts of confirmed COVID-19 cases, provides PPE kits, hand & respiratory hygiene materials, and other needed supplies to Rapid Response Teams, conducts public awareness campaign on local radio in high risk areas, supports of four blood banks with equipment, and equips six hospitals for Emergency Triage Assessment and Treatment (ETAT) among other activities. The project provides life-saving assistance to 304,000 people, including 27,500 women, 56,500 men, over 200,000 children, and 8,310 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Identification and redressal of GBV in refugee and host populations through community-based mechanisms

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to address life-saving needs of GBV survivors in COVID 19-affected areas and provide livelihood support. This UNWOMEN project provides 25 community outreach groups, awareness-raising sessions, FGDs and GBV counselling sessions to refugee and host populations, dignity kits to 2,500 women, and 160 care packages and dignity kits to People with Disabilities (PWD). The project provides life-saving assistance to 16,000 people, including 6,000 women, 2,000 men, 8,000 children, and 320 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Emergency Protection and GBV Response for Women and Girls in Host Communities and GBV Shelters.

description.narrative: The project aims to enhance protection of the most vulnerable women and girls affected by the impacts of Covid-19, GBV and SGBV in urban Kampala and host communities in Uganda’s refugee-hosting districts. UN Women is proposing a three-pronged, approach to address SGBV in the context of COVID-19: 1) increased access to emergency SGBV services through integrated and survivor-centered life-saving service delivery; strengthened capacity of existing community-based mechanisms for enhanced protection, prevention and response to SGBV; and reduced GBV risks by supporting access to time-critical, life-saving, protection services as well as unrestricted, multi-purpose cash transfers for access to basic life-saving needs, and livelihoods for GBV survivors. he project will benefit a total ofo f26,170 13,930 women and girls as direct beneficiaries, including 700 women and girls with disabilities.

title.narrative: GBV in the context of COVID-19 pandemic: Gender-sensitive and life-saving response for most affected and at-risk women, in Nariño and Chocó

description.narrative: The main aim of this $307,275 UN Women project is to strengthen the public institutions in supporting non-medical services, both in person and remote, to address GBV during COVID-19 pandemic. To that end, UN Women will provide technical support and equipment (including PPE, telecommunications equipment, internet and mobile data) to five local institutions, update and implement two referral pathways, and provide 900 resilience kits and orientation on GBV prevention to most-at risk women and men. In total, UN Women will reach 900 people directly, including 850 women and 50 men (and 50 persons with disabilities). In addition, an estimated 3,000 persons, including community members, members of local community councils, and staff of state institutions will have access to the project’s lifesaving information and key messages.

The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health assistance to vulnerable communities at risk of spread of EVD outside Guinea. This UNICEF project will provide support for coordination, capacity building of first line responders, increased knowledge and empowerment of the communities and distribution of critical supplies. UNICEF will help to scale up Health, risk communication and community engagement (RCCE), Infection Prevention and Control (IPC)/WASH, and psychosocial care interventions at the community, school and healthcare facility levels to prevent the spread of Ebola Virus Disease. The project provides life-saving assistance people, including 2,047,804 women, 1,748,024 men and 4,355,778 children.

title.narrative: Addressing WASH and Education needs of children and communities impacted by inter-tribal conflicts in West Darfur

description.narrative:
This project aims to assure expansion and continuation of multi-sectoral lifesaving humanitarian assistance to people displaced in West Darfur, with particular attention to women and girls.
In West Darfur, intercommunal conflict and violence erupted on 15 January 2021 inside Geneina town. Approximately 169.000 people have been displaced across Geneina locality, including 77 gathering points inside the town, 39 affected villages, including 6 nomadic settlements surrounding Geneina town. Out of the displaced population, children are estimated to be 62% (24,464 boys and 37,336 girls) (IOM).
To ensure continuity of and improved access to quality education for 12,192 boys and 8,358 girls from the IDPs and host community, the project will establish and/or rehabilitate 119 classrooms. Moreover, capacities of 510 teachers/PTA will be strengthened to provide quality education, through refresher trainings.
Furthermore, this project is going to focus on 20 gathering points in Geneina town and 10 villages, including nomad villages surrounding Geneina to improve access to water and sanitation in both Massalit and Arab tribe communities over next six months. These 20 gathering points are currently not served by any of WASH sector partners and remains as a critical gap. Water trucking in 20 gathering points will be organized while working on the expansion of town water supply network for more sustainable water supply for the gathering points, many of them are public facilities such as local government office or schools. For nomad communities, five Water Yards are planned to be built under this project. For sanitation and hygiene, most of the activities target gathering points where population density is high and risk of communicable disease outbreak (including COVID-19) is higher.
The project targets a total of 21,059 affected people with its Education component and 60,000 affected people with its WASH component.

title.narrative: Provision of Life-Saving Nutrition and WASH Services to emergency-affected vulnerable populations

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide essential Nutrition and WASH services to children, women and communities affected by conflict, drought and the impact of COVID-19. This UNICEF project 1) distributes therapeutic supplies to people with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM), 2) provides hygiene supplies and 3) installs emergency sanitation facilities among other activities. The project provides life-saving assistance to 80,000 people, including 21,700 women, 22,900 men, 35,400 children, and 3,400 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Emergency water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) response to conflict-affected populations in Tigray Region

description.narrative: The main objective of this project this WASH response is to provide life-saving WASH services and supplies for the affected population, including children displaced due to the conflict in Tigray, reaching an anticipated 280,000 persons (directly). This UNICEF project provides freshwater supply through emergency water trucking and rehabilitation of water systems, construction of emergency latrines, building of handwashing facilities, promotion of hygiene practices including risk communication and community education (RCCE) for COVID-19, and distribution of life-saving WASH NFI. The project provides life-saving assistance to 280,000 people, including 53,200 women, 47,600 men,179,200 children, and 47,600 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Anticipatory livelihood protection to minimise drought impacts and safeguard food security

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to protect livelihoods and safeguard food and nutrition security of vulnerable households from the adverse impacts of drought and other recent shocks. title.narrative: Provision of Site Management Support for Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in Tigray Region

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to Provide Site Management Support for Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in Tigray. This UNHCR project intends to ensure that the displaced populations have access to information on available humanitarian services through communication with communities (CwC), alongside key messaging on COVID-19, which is vital during this time the collective sites hosting displaced persons are highly congested. CCCM shall ensure the sites are managed better through site improvement activities, including installing proper drainage systems, internal road networks, and the construction of communal halls and distribution sites. With the allocated resources, the cluster will engage technical support to repair and rehabilitate the current Six (6) IDP Collective Sites among 11 managed by UNHCR, which require appropriate expertise to restore the structures to favorable conditions. The project provides life-saving assistance to 468,725 people, including 98,011 women,94,167 men,276,547 children, and 7,500 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Provision of Emergency Shelter and Camp Coordination and Camp Management Assistance for Populations Affected by the Northern Ethiopian Crisis and COVID-19-Related Health Services for Humanitarian Actors in Tigray

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving Emergency Shelter and Camp Coordination and Camp Management Assistance for Populations affected by the Northern Ethiopian crisis and COVID-19-related health services for humanitarian actors in Tigray. This IOM project provides Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM) interventions targeting 12 internally displaced persons (IDP) sites; emergency shelter assistance targeting 72,000 IDPs; COVID-19 related health services for staff from United Nations (UN), Humanitarian International Non-Governmental Organizations (HINGOs), and National NGOs (NNGOs). Proposed interventions address urgent gaps and needs identified through multi-sector assessments in the Tigray region, particularly lack of emergency shelters, inadequate /missing coordination of IDP sites, and lack of COVID-19 testing for staff deployed to this emergency. The project provides life-saving assistance to 251,073 people, including 53,241 women,51,890 men, 145,942 children, and 12,552 people with disabilities.

title.narrative: Logistics response - Equatorial Guinea Bata explosions

description.narrative: The overall objective of this project is to support the Logistics sector, which has been identified as critical and urgent in the delivery of life saving support to affected communities in Bata. This WFP project provide UNHAS services by establishing an air bridge between Malabo and Bata to enable emergency personnel and equipment to be transported quickly and regularly. One aircraft B1900D will be based in Malabo operating the route Malabo-Bata-Malabo. The aircraft capacity is of 19 passengers, however due to COVID-19 restrictions, capacity will be reduced to 50%: with approximately 20 passengers per day – round trip from Monday to Friday / An estimated 450 passengers per month will use UNHAS assets.

title.narrative: Humanitarian Air Services and Emergency telecommunications response to the crisis in Tigray

description.narrative: The main objective of this WFP project is to provide timely and urgent life-saving local medical evacuation within Ethiopia for COVID-19 related cases and other medical evacuations to eligible humanitarian/development actors working in Tigray Region. The Emergency Telecommunications Sector (ETS) will provide communications and technology services in up to three common operational areas. Reliable security communications services will be enhanced and delivered to the humanitarian community in Mekelle, Shire, and Embamadre, working with UNDSS and the ICT Emergency Cell to provide equipment and personnel for the Security Operations Centres (SOCs). WFP will support access to the network through the programming of radios for those who have authorized licensed equipment. The ETS will also explore and assist humanitarian organizations with options to access Internet services through national providers and potentially use satellite communications, where applicable. The ETS team will share with humanitarian actors and comply with the government guidelines on the use of telecommunications equipment.

title.narrative: West Africa Ebola Virus Disease Readiness project

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving health assistance to vulnerable communities at risk of spread of Ebola virus disease in Sierra Leone, Liberia, Cote D'Ivoire, Mali, Senegal and Guinea-Bissau. This WHO project will support operations of the Public Health Emergency Operation Centre’s to curtail the EVD outbreak at national and subnational level, conduct Ebola virus disease surveillance, scale-up EVD prevention efforts at Points of Entry and provide technical support for Ebola virus disease laboratory diagnosis and case management. The project provides life-saving assistance to 33,139,174 people, including 8,410,699 women, men and 16,839,083 children and 2,752 people with disabilities in health sector.

title.narrative: Supporting the emergency health response to population displacements due to inter-communal conflict in El Geneina, West Darfur

description.narrative:
The project supports the emergency health response after internal displacement due to inter-communal violence in the area of El Geneina in West Darfur. The objective of the project is to improve access to and quality of health care for the IDP population and thus, to contribute to a reduction of morbidity and mortality in the target population. The project comprises the following activities: - Procurement and supplies of essential medicines, diagnostics and basic equipment for primary health care and referral health facilities including Covid-19 related IPC supplies and diagnostics tests - Operational support to 7 mobile and/or fixed primary health care facilities implemented through NGO partners or the SMOH including isolation centres in case of a Covid-19 outbreak in El Geneina during the implementation period - Strengthening medical waste management in primary and secondary health care facilities receiving IDPs in El Geneina and its surroundings through medical waste management campaigns - Strengthen disease surveillance and rapid response teams interventions in order to improve early detection, tracing and containment of diseases with epidemic potential among the vulnerable population - Strengthen vector surveillance in order to orient vector control interventions of health partners and WHO with the aim to reduce the transmission in the IDP and host community
The project targets 135,000 affected people.

title.narrative: Lifesaving Health Services to conflict affected communities in Northern Ethiopia

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving essential health services and protection for the most vulnerable crisis-affected population. This WHO project will provide prevention and containment of diseases and Cholera preparedness interventions.The project will also support the resumption of COVID-19 response and strengthen the malaria prevention and response interventions, detect and care for people with mental health and psychosocial needs, strengthen the Tigray Regional Health Bureau (TRHB) and woreda health systems and the capacity to respond to malnutrition prevention and management especially for SAM with complications and strengthen ongoing heightened surveillance for epidemics as well as streamline the supply chain management. The project provides life-saving assistance to 418,000 people, including 102,334 women, 98,337 men,217,329 children, and 73,568 people with disabilities.

description.narrative: 1- Disinfect school infrastructure, furniture and teaching and learning supplies to ensure the safe return to schools. Ensure that children affected by the COVID-19 pandemic have access to appropriate alternative care arrangements and provide them with psychosocial support. 2- Training and capacity building of child protection professionals on the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on children in preparation for isolated or therapeutic cases, including psychosocial impacts. 3-Supporting the Ministry of Education in Somalia by providing educational supplies to continue the educational process online.
At least 18,250 direct beneficiaries (3250 beneficiaries from the education sector - 15,000 beneficiaries from the protection sector).
